In 1967 the official definition of the second was first given by the BIPM at the 13th General Conference on Weights and Measures, it was defined as being "equal to the time duration of 9 192 631 770 periods of the radiation corresponding to the transition between the two hyperfine levels of the fundamental unperturbed ground-state of the caesium-133 atom." So from this caesium standard definition of the second it follows that the radiation in question has a frequency of exactly 9.19263177 GHz, corresponding to a wavelength of about 3.26 cm. So a second is only 3.26 cm away. :)

You're only argument here doesn't make much sense. Yes, in most cases we do only care about time. That doesn't make it "irrelevant and wrong" though. If we say 10 lightyears, we mean 10 years travelling at the speed of light. If we say 10 minutes(assuming we are riding a bike and at the same speed as everyone else does), we mean 10 minutes travelling at the speed of a bike. now obviously light has a set speed and bicycles don't, but it is still the best way I can think of to explain lightyears.

When we say a shop is 10 minutes away, we mean a rough estimation of the time it would take to get there. We care more about the time than the distance, as we only want to know how much of our day going to the shops would take.

When we say light-years, we really don't care about time much at all. A light-year is a fixed, precise unit of distance, of how far light travels in a year - about 9 trillion kilometres. Comparing light-years to '10 minutes to the shop' is irrelevant and wrong.

Film is about .0001 m thick, so (Area)/10^4, or the area with the decimal moved to the left 4 places. For ZakX11's version of the area, it would be .050625 m^3. For my version of the area, it would be .00002592 m^3. Either way you look at it, extremely small.

Are you implying the the 16:9 ratio refers to the length of the entire film vs the height of the entire film? That's not quite how film works... for a 16:9 ratio, each frame needs to have that ratio. That means that if the frame is 16 mm in length, it is 9 mm in height. This gives 144 mm^2 as the area of one frame. 30 frames per second for 60 seconds is 1800 frames, so 144 mm^2/frame*1800 frames=259200 mm^2, or .2592 m^2. An area of 506.25 m^2 would be a video 1.36 days long.

I was hoping that this video would be about the theoretical absolute smallest possible distance that can be traveled and its relation to the theoretical absolute smallest possible amount of time that can pass. Assuming that these are the same, we can use the same unit of measurement for both time and space. We could then determine how many of these units it takes to equal a meter. When that's done, we can measure time with the metric system.

251,968 miles (farthest point, apogee)
251968 / 3 miles per hour = 83989.333333 hours
83989.333333 / 24 = 3,499.55556 days
3,499.55556 / 365.2425 (average days in a year) = 9.58145769 years

236,715.5 miles is the midpoint
236715.5 / 3 miles per hour = 78905.1667 hours
78905.1667 / 24 = 3,287.71528 days
3287.71528 / 365.2425 = (average days in a year) 9.0014587 years

Exact average number of days in a year = 365 + 1/4 - 1/100 + 1/400 = 365.2425 = 365 days, 5 hours, 49 minutes, and 12 seconds

The moon is approximately 231,463 miles at perigee (closest point) to approximately 251,968 miles at apogee (farthest point). Assume you are walking at three miles an hour.

231,463 miles (closest point, perigee)
231463 / 3 miles per hour = 77154.333333 hours
77154.333333 / 24 = 3,214.76389 days
3214.76389 / 365.2425 (average days in a year) = 8.80172458 years

It would take approximately 8 years, 292 days, 19 hours, 46 minutes, and 24.096 seconds if you walk at a constant, uninterrupted speed of 3 miles per hour toward the closest point the moon gets to the Earth (called the perigee).

--> Standard NTSC/Pal for cinema: 24 frames per sec
==> 2136 frames.
The frame-height is 16 mm (academic size).  ==> ~ 34,2 meters.

Initially the second used to be defined by the earths rotation around the sun (1/31,556,925.9747 of the year 1900). However people started to realize that there were several problems with this definition:
1. It can never be measured again, the year 1900 is over and the length of a year varies.
2. It's not a very precise definition.
When atomic clocks where developed people then came up with the idea to redefine our second as a specific amount of cycles of an atomic clock.
